title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: List and hearken, gentlemen,
title: Robin Hood

text: That be of free-born blood,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: I shall you tell of a good yeoman,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: His name was Robin Hood.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Robin was a proud outlaw,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: While as he walked on the ground.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: So courteous an outlaw as he was one
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Was never none else found.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: In the days of good King Harry the Second of England--he of the warring
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: sons--there were certain forests in the north country set aside for the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: King's hunting, and no man might shoot deer therein under penalty of
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: death. These forests were guarded by the King's Foresters, the chief
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: of whom, in each wood, was no mean man but equal in authority to the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Sheriff in his walled town, or even to my lord Bishop in his abbey.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: One of the greatest of royal preserves was Sherwood and Barnesdale
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: forests near the two towns of Nottingham and Barnesdale. Here for some
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: years dwelt one Hugh Fitzooth as Head Forester, with his good wife and
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: son Robert. The boy had been born in Lockesley town--in the year 1160,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: stern records say--and was often called Lockesley, or Rob of Lockesley.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: He was a comely, well-knit stripling, and as soon as he was strong
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: enough to walk his chief delight was to go with his father into the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: forest. As soon as his right arm received thew and sinew he learned to
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: draw the long bow and speed a true arrow. While on winter evenings his
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: greatest joy was to hear his father tell of bold Will o' the Green, the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: outlaw, who for many summers defied the King's Foresters and feasted
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: with his men upon King's deer. And on other stormy days the boy learned
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: to whittle out a straight shaft for the long bow, and tip it with gray
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: goose feathers.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: The fond mother sighed when she saw the boy's face light up at these
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: woodland tales. She was of gentle birth, and had hoped to see her son
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: famous at court or abbey. She taught him to read and to write, to doff
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: his cap without awkwardness and to answer directly and truthfully both
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: lord and peasant. But the boy, although he took kindly to these lessons
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: of breeding, was yet happiest when he had his beloved bow in hand and
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: strolled at will, listening to the murmur of the trees.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Two playmates had Rob in these gladsome early days. One was Will
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Gamewell, his father's brother's son, who lived at Gamewell Lodge, hard
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: by Nottingham town. The other was Marian Fitzwalter, only child of the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Earl of Huntingdon. The castle of Huntingdon could be seen from the top
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: of one of the tall trees in Sherwood; and on more than one bright day
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Rob's white signal from this tree told Marian that he awaited her there:
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: for you must know that Rob did not visit her at the castle. His father
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: and her father were enemies. Some people whispered that Hugh Fitzooth
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: was the rightful Earl of Huntingdon, but that he had been defrauded out
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: of his lands by Fitzwalter, who had won the King's favor by a crusade to
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the Holy Land. But little cared Rob or Marian for this enmity, however
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: it had arisen. They knew that the great green--wood was open to them,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: and that the wide, wide world was full of the scent of flowers and the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: song of birds.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Days of youth speed all too swiftly, and troubled skies come all too
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: soon. Rob's father had two other enemies besides Fitzwalter, in
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the persons of the lean Sheriff of Nottingham and the fat Bishop of
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Hereford. These three enemies one day got possession of the King's ear
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: and whispered therein to such good--or evil--purpose that Hugh Fitzooth
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: was removed from his post of King's Forester. He and his wife and Rob,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: then a youth of nineteen, were descended upon, during a cold winter's
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: evening, and dispossessed without warning. The Sheriff arrested the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Forester for treason--of which, poor man, he was as guiltless as you or
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: I--and carried him to Nottingham jail. Rob and his mother were sheltered
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: over night in the jail, also, but next morning were roughly bade to go
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: about their business. Thereupon they turned for succor to their only
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: kinsman, Squire George of Gamewell, who sheltered them in all kindness.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: But the shock, and the winter night's journey, proved too much for
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Dame Fitzooth. She had not been strong for some time before leaving the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: forest. In less than two months she was no more. Rob felt as though his
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: heart was broken at this loss. But scarcely had the first spring flowers
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: begun to blossom upon her grave, when he met another crushing blow in
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the loss of his father. That stern man had died in prison before his
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: accusers could agree upon the charges by which he was to be brought to
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: trial.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Two years passed by. Rob's cousin Will was away at school; and Marian's
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: father, who had learned of her friendship with Rob, had sent his
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: daughter to the court of Queen Eleanor. So these years were lonely ones
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: to the orphaned lad. The bluff old Squire was kind to him, but secretly
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: could make nothing of one who went about brooding and as though seeking
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: for something he had lost. The truth is that Rob missed his old life
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: in the forest no less than his mother's gentleness, and his father's
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: companionship. Every time he twanged the string of the long bow against
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: his shoulder and heard the gray goose shaft sing, it told him of happy
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: days that he could not recall.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: One morning as Rob came in to breakfast, his uncle greeted him with, "I
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: have news for you, Rob, my lad!" and the hearty old Squire finished his
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: draught of ale and set his pewter tankard down with a crash.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "What may that be, Uncle Gamewell?" asked the young man.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Here is a chance to exercise your good long bow and win a pretty prize.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: The Fair is on at Nottingham, and the Sheriff proclaims an archer's
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: tournament. The best fellows are to have places with the King's
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Foresters, and the one who shoots straightest of all will win for prize
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: a golden arrow--a useless bauble enough, but just the thing for your lady
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: love, eh, Rob my boy?" Here the Squire laughed and whacked the table
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: again with his tankard.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Rob's eyes sparkled. "'Twere indeed worth shooting for, uncle mine," he
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: said. "I should dearly love to let arrow fly alongside another man. And
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: a place among the Foresters is what I have long desired. Will you let me
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: try?"
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "To be sure," rejoined his uncle. "Well I know that your good mother
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: would have had me make a clerk of you; but well I see that the greenwood
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: is where you will pass your days. So, here's luck to you in the bout!"
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: And the huge tankard came a third time into play.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: The young man thanked his uncle for his good wishes, and set about
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: making preparations for the journey. He traveled lightly; but his yew
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: bow must needs have a new string, and his cloth-yard arrows must be of
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the straightest and soundest.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: One fine morning, a few days after, Rob might have been seen passing
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: by way of Lockesley through Sherwood Forest to Nottingham town. Briskly
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: walked he and gaily, for his hopes were high and never an enemy had he
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: in the wide world. But 'twas the very last morning in all his life
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: when he was to lack an enemy! For, as he went his way through Sherwood,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: whistling a blithe tune, he came suddenly upon a group of Foresters,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: making merry beneath the spreading branches of an oak-tree. They had a
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: huge meat pie before them and were washing down prodigious slices of it
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: with nut brown ale.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: One glance at the leader and Rob knew at once that he had found
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: an enemy. 'Twas the man who had usurped his father's place as Head
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Forester, and who had roughly turned his mother out in the snow. But
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: never a word said he for good or bad, and would have passed on his way,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: had not this man, clearing his throat with a huge gulp, bellowed out:
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "By my troth, here is a pretty little archer! Where go you, my lad, with
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: that tupenny bow and toy arrows? Belike he would shoot at Nottingham
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Fair! Ho! Ho!"
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: A roar of laughter greeted this sally. Rob flushed, for he was mightily
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: proud of his shooting.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "My bow is as good as yours," he retorted, "and my shafts will carry as
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: straight and as far. So I'll not take lessons of any of ye."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: They laughed again loudly at this, and the leader said with frown:
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Show us some of your skill, and if you can hit the mark here's twenty
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: silver pennies for you. But if you hit it not you are in for a sound
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: drubbing for your pertness."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Pick your own target," quoth Rob in a fine rage. "I'll lay my head
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: against that purse that I can hit it."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "It shall be as you say," retorted the Forester angrily, "your head for
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: your sauciness that you hit not my target."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Now at a little rise in the wood a herd of deer came grazing by, distant
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: full fivescore yards. They were King's deer, but at that distance seemed
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: safe from any harm. The Head Forester pointed to them.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "If your young arm could speed a shaft for half that distance, I'd shoot
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: with you."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Done!" cried Rob. "My head against twenty pennies I'll cause yon fine
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: fellow in the lead of them to breathe his last."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: And without more ado he tried the string of his long bow, placed a shaft
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: thereon, and drew it to his ear. A moment, and the quivering string sang
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: death as the shaft whistled across the glade. Another moment and the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: leader of the herd leaped high in his tracks and fell prone, dyeing the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: sward with his heart's blood.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: A murmur of amazement swept through the Foresters, and then a growl of
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: rage. He that had wagered was angriest of all.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Know you what you have done, rash youth?" he said. "You have killed a
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: King's deer, and by the laws of King Harry your head remains forfeit.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Talk not to me of pennies but get ye gone straight, and let me not look
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: upon your face again."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Rob's blood boiled within him, and he uttered a rash speech. "I have
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: looked upon your face once too often already, my fine Forester. 'Tis you
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: who wear my father's shoes."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: And with this he turned upon his heel and strode away.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: The Forester heard his parting thrust with an oath. Red with rage he
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: seized his bow, strung an arrow, and without warning launched it full
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: af' Rob. Well was it for the latter that the Forester's foot turned on a
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: twig at the critical instant, for as it was the arrow whizzed by his ear
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: so close as to take a stray strand of his hair with it. Rob turned upon
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: his assailant, now twoscore yards away.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Ha!" said he. "You shoot not so straight as I, for all your bravado.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Take this from the tupenny bow!"
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Straight flew his answering shaft. The Head Forester gave one cry, then
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: fell face downward and lay still. His life had avenged Rob's father, but
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the son was outlawed. Forward he ran through the forest, before the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: band could gather their scattered wits--still forward into the great
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: greenwood. The swaying trees seemed to open their arms to the wanderer,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: and to welcome him home.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Toward the close of the same day, Rob paused hungry and weary at the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: cottage of a poor widow who dwelt upon the outskirts of the forest. Now
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: this widow had often greeted him kindly in his boyhood days, giving him
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: gladly join your band, and you take me, as a common archer. For there
title: Robin Hood

text: are others older and mayhap more skilled than I."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Then stepped one forward from the rest, a tall swarthy man. And Rob
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: recognized him as the man with the green blinder; only this was now
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: removed, and his freed eye gleamed as stoutly as the other one.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Rob in the Hood--for such the lady called you," said he, "I can vouch
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: for your tale. You shamed the Sheriff e'en as I had hoped to do; and we
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: can forego the golden arrow since it is in such fair hands. As to your
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: shooting and mine, we must let future days decide. But here I, Will
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Stutely, declare that I will serve none other chief save only you."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: every one, right gladly; because Will Stutely had heretofore been the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: truest bow in all the company. And they toasted him in nut brown ale,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: and hailed him as their leader, by the name of Robin Hood. And he
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: accepted that name because Maid Marian had said it.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: By the light of the camp-fire the band exchanged signs and passwords.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: They gave Robin Hood a horn upon which he was to blow to summon them.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: They swore, also, that while they might take money and goods from the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: unjust rich, they would aid and befriend the poor and the helpless; and
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: that they would harm no woman, be she maid, wife, or widow. They swore
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: all this with solemn oaths, while they feasted about the ruddy blaze,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: under the greenwood tree.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: And that is how Robin Hood became an outlaw.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: It had come around another Fair day at Nottingham town, and folk crowded
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: there by all the gates. Goods of many kinds were displayed in gaily
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: colored booths, and at every cross-street a free show was in progress.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Here and there, stages had been erected for the play at quarter-staff, a
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: highly popular sport.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: There was a fellow, one Eric of Lincoln, who was thought to be the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: finest man with the staff for miles around. His feats were sung about in
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: ballads through all the shire. A great boaster was he withal, and to-day
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: he strutted about on one of these corner stages, and vaunted of his
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: prowess, and offered to crack any man's crown for a shilling. Several
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: had tried their skill with Eric, but he had soon sent them spinning in
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: no gentle manner, amid the jeers and laughter of the onlookers.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: A beggar-man sat over against Eric's stage and grinned every time a pate
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: was cracked. He was an uncouth fellow, ragged and dirty and unshaven.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Eric caught sight of his leering face at one of his boasts--for there
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: was a lull in the game, because no man else wanted to come within reach
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: of Eric's blows. Eric, I say, noticed the beggar-man grinning at him
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: rather impudently, and turned toward him sharply.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "How now, you dirty villain!" quoth he, "mend your manners to your
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: betters, or, by our Lady, I'll dust your rags for you."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: The beggar-man still grinned. "I am always ready to mend my manners to
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: my betters," said he, "but I am afraid you cannot teach me any better
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: than you can dust my jacket."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Come up! Come up!" roared the other, flourishing his staff.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "That will I," said the beggar, getting up slowly and with difficulty.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: good man will lend me a stout quarter-staff."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: their own--and he took the stoutest and heaviest of all. He made a sorry
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: enough figure as he climbed awkwardly upon the stage, but when he had
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: laughed in great glee.

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: stage, launched forth boldly and gave the other a sounding crack on the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: shoulder. The beggar danced about, and made as though he would drop his
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: staff from very pain, while the crowd roared and Eric raised himself for
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: another crushing blow. But just then the awkward beggar came to life.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the like of which he had never before seen. Down went the boaster to the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: themselves purple; for it was a new sight to see Eric of Lincoln eating
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: retreated to his own ringside to gather his wits and watch for an
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: were on their guard and fenced with fine skill, being well matched in
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: prowess. Again and again did Eric seek to force an opening under the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: stood sturdily in his tracks contenting himself with beating off the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: direction. The victory of the queer beggar made him immensely popular.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: at his hands. So the ragged stranger found money and food and drink

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: fellow?"

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

title: Robin Hood

author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Gamewell Lodge, where the old Squire George wept for joy at seeing his
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: son and the King and the wedding--party. That night they spent there,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: and feasted, and the next day, Sir Richard of the Lea claimed them.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: And thus, amid feasting and rejoicing and kingly favor, Robin Hood, the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: new Earl of Huntingdon, and his bride began their wedded life.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: CHAPTER XXIV
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: HOW ROBIN HOOD MET HIS DEATH
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Give me my bent bow in my hand,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: And a broad arrow I'll let flee;
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: And where this arrow is taken up,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: There shall my grave digg'd be."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Now by good rights this story should end with the wedding of Robin Hood
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: and Maid Marian; for do not many pleasant tales end with a wedding and
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the saying, "and they lived happy ever after."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: But this is a true account--in so far as we can find the quaint old
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: ballads which tell of it--and so we must follow one more of these songs
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: and learn how Robin, after living many years longer, at last came to
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: seek his grave. And the story of it runs in this wise.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Robin Hood and his men, now the Royal Archers, went with King Richard of
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the Lion Heart through England settling certain private disputes which
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: had arisen among the Norman barons while the King was gone to the Holy
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Land. Then the King proceeded amid great pomp and rejoicing to the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: palace at London, and Robin, the new Earl of Huntingdon, brought his
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Countess thither, where she became one of the finest ladies of the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Court.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: The Royal Archers were now divided into two bands, and one-half of them
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: were retained in London, while the other half returned to Sherwood and
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Barnesdale, there to guard the King's preserves.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Several months passed by, and Robin began to chafe under the restraint
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: of city life. He longed for the fresh pure air of the greenwood, and
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the rollicking society of his yeomen. One day, upon seeing some lads
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: at archery practice upon a green, he could not help but lament, saying,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Woe is me! I fear my hand is fast losing its old time cunning at the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: bow-string!"
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Finally he became so distraught that he asked leave to travel in foreign
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: lands, and this was granted him. He took Maid Marian with him, and
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: together they went through many strange countries. Finally in an Eastern
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: land a great grief came upon Robin. Marian sickened of a plague and
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: died. They had been married but five years, and Robin felt as though all
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the light had gone out of his life.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: He wandered about the world for a few months longer, trying to forget
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: his grief, then came back to the court, at London, and sought some
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: commission in active service. But unluckily, Richard was gone again upon
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: his adventures, and Prince John, who acted as Regent, had never been
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: fond of Robin. He received him with a sarcastic smile.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Go forth into the greenwood," said he, coldly, "and kill some more of
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the King's deer. Belike, then, the King will make you Prime Minister, at
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the very least, upon his return."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: The taunt fired Robin's blood. He had been in a morose mood, ever since
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: his dear wife's death. He answered Prince John hotly, and the Prince
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: bade his guards seize him and cast him into the Tower.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: After lying there for a few weeks, he was released by the faithful
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Stutely and the remnant of the Royal Archers, and all together they fled
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the city and made their way to the greenwood. There Robin blew the old
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: familiar call, which all had known and loved so well. Up came running
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the remainder of the band, who had been Royal Foresters, and when they
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: saw their old master they embraced his knees and kissed his hands, and
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: fairly cried for joy that he had come again to them. And one and all
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: forswore fealty to Prince John, and lived quietly with Robin in the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: greenwood, doing harm to none and only awaiting the time when King
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Richard should come again.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: But King Richard came not again, and would never need his Royal Guard
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: more. Tidings presently reached them, of how he had met his death in a
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: foreign land, and how John reigned as King in his stead. The proof of
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: these events followed soon after, when there came striding through the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: glade the big, familiar form of Little John.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Art come to arrest us?" called out Robin, as he ran forward and
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: embraced his old comrade.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Nay, I am not come as the Sheriff of Nottingham, thanks be," answered
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Little John. "The new King has deposed me, and 'tis greatly to
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: my liking, for I have long desired to join you here again in the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: greenwood."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Then were the rest of the band right glad at this news, and toasted
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Little John royally.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: The new King waged fierce war upon the outlaws, soon after this, and
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: sent so many scouting parties into Sherwood and Barnesdale that Robin
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: and his men left these woods for a time and went into Derbyshire, near
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Haddon Hall. A curious pile of stone is shown to this day as the ruins
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: of Robin's Castle, where the bold outlaw is believed to have defied his
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: enemies for a year or more. At any rate King John found so many troubles
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: of his own, after a time, that he ceased troubling the outlaws.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: But in one of the last sorties Robin was wounded. The cut did not seem
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: serious, and healed over the top; but it left a lurking fever. Daily his
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: strength ebbed away from him, until he was in sore distress.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: One day as he rode along on horseback, near Kirklees Abbey, he was
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: seized with so violent a rush of blood to the head that he reeled and
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: came near falling from his saddle. He dismounted weakly and knocked at
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the Abbey gate. A woman shrouded in black peered forth.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Who are you that knock here? For we allow no man within these walls,"
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: she said.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Open, for the love of Heaven!" he begged. "I am Robin Hood, ill of a
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: fever and in sore straits."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: At the name of Robin Hood the woman started back, and then, as though
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: bethinking herself, unbarred the door and admitted him. Assisting his
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: fainting frame up a flight of stairs and into a front room, she loosed
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: his collar and bathed his face until he was revived. Then she spoke
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: hurriedly in a low voice:
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Your fever will sink, if you are bled. See, I have provided a lancet
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: and will open your veins, while you lie quiet."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: So she bled him, and he fell into a stupor which lasted nearly all that
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: day, so that he awoke weak and exhausted from loss of blood.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Now there is a dispute as to this abbess who bled him. Some say that
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: she did it in all kindness of heart; while others aver that she was none
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: other than the former Sheriff's daughter, and found her revenge at last
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: in this cruel deed.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Be that as it may, Robin's eyes swam from very weakness when he awoke.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: He called wearily for help, but there was no response. He looked
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: longingly through the window at the green of the forest; but he was too
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: weak to make the leap that would be needed to reach the ground.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: He then bethought him of his horn,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Which hung down at his knee;
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: He set his horn unto his mouth,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: And blew out weak blasts three.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Little John was out in the forest near by, or the blasts would never
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: have been heard. At their sound he sprang to his feet.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Woe! woe!" he cried, "I fear my master is near dead, he blows so
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: wearily!"
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: So he made haste and came running up to the door of the abbey, and
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: knocked loudly for admittance. Failing to get reply, he burst in the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: door with frenzied blows of his mighty fist, and soon came running up
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: to the room where Robin lay, white and faint. "Alas, dear master!" cried
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Little John in great distress; "I fear you have met with treachery! If
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: that be so, grant me one last boon, I pray."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "What is it?" asked Robin.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Let me burn Kirklees-Hall with fire, and all its nunnery."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Nay, good comrade," answered Robin Hood gently, "I cannot grant such
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: a boon. The dear Christ bade us forgive all our enemies. Moreover,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: you know I never hurt woman in all my life; nor man when in woman's
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: company."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: He closed his eyes and fell back, so that his friend thought him dying.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: The great tears fell from the giant's eyes and wet his master's hand.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Robin slowly rallied and seized his comrade's outstretched arm.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Lift me up, good Little John," he said brokenly, "I want to smell
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the air from the good greenwood once again. Give me my good yew
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: bow--here--here-and fix a broad arrow upon the string. Out yonder--among
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: the oaks--where this arrow shall fall--let them dig my grave."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: And with one last mighty effort he sped his shaft out of the open
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: window, straight and true, as in the days of old, till it struck the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: largest oak of them all and dropped in the shadow of the trees. Then he
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: fell back upon the sobbing breast of his devoted friend.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "'Tis the last!" he murmured, "tell the brave hearts to lay me there
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: with the green sod under my head and feet. And--let them lay--my bent
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: bow at my side, for it has made sweet music in mine ears."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: He rested a moment, and Little John scarce knew that he was alive. But
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: on a sudden Robin's eye brightened, and he seemed to think himself back
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: once more with the band in the open forest glade. He struggled to rise.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Ha! 'tis a fine stag, Will! And Allan, thou never didst thrum the harp
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: more sweetly. How the light blazes! And Marian!--'tis my Marian--come at
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: last!"
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: So died the body of Robin Hood; but his spirit lives on through the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: centuries in the deathless ballads which are sung of him, and in the
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: hearts of men who love freedom and chivalry.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: They buried him where his last arrow had fallen, and they set a stone to
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: mark the spot. And on the stone were graven these words:
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: "Here underneath his little stone
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Lies Robert, Earl of Huntingdon;
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Never archer as he so good,
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: And people called him Robin Hood.
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Such outlaws as he and his men
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)

text: Will England never see again."
title: Robin Hood
author: McSpadden, J. Walker (Joseph Walker)
